div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: RETRIBUTION.

The telegram received from onr London Correspondent yesterday giving a list of ex- Cabinet Ministers who have been rajeoted at the poll*, as well as the figmes which we publish .te-^iay, affords an nnfailing iadioa- tien of the complete rout of the Unionist Party, and the nation seems to have tamed towards a hope of better, things, as promised by the Liberals, with a seal which oan on'y be due to an intense weariness of the ,b»rro>v resalts .of these latter .years, have in thti field of foreign politics, the outcome of Mr; Balfour's leadership has,little, to show. Pint and foremost, what the nation desired after the close of the Boer war was. the reform: of the Army. Bat Mr. Arnold Forster's efforts in this direotion have been as hopeless as,.arid caaeed more irritation than, the ineffectual schemes of his predecessor at. the War Office, Mr. Brod rick. Tha Education Act has only pleased the Anglioan supporters of thd Government, whilst it has totally alienated that large and influential body of Non- oonfortaist* who left, the Gladstonian fold in vast numbers rather than allow the Protestants of Ireland, to be handed over to Oatholio domination. The agrionltural labourer, who was rbnsed from his indiffsrenoe by promises of Old Age Pensions, has been totally neglected, while the middle classes have seen that the ohly results of these years of Unionist sway lias been the inorease and steady maintenance .of the Inoome Tax. The country gentUimen and farmers, whose enthusiasm ahonld have been aroaaed by Mr. Cham- berlaid'a conversion to Pair Trade, have had their ardonr damped by the logioal refinements with Whioh the Premier maintained—it must, be. confessed with wonderful skill—his equivocal position between his Prep Trade and Proteotionist partisans. Another item which has gone to swell the Radioal ranks has undoubtedly been the slackness of the Govern- ment in dealing with the question of the unemployed, which has lately balked so largely in the public view. Also mast be borne in mind the defeotion of the Dake of Devonshire; Lord George Hamilton, and other prominent poli- doians from the proposals of the Government, for it mast have undoubtedly oansed a large loss of votes.' "A house divided against itself cannot stend," and far above many of .the matters Al?oye-mentipned which contributed to the Unionist ddb&ole mast be reckoned the consideration that the average voter deolined to return to Parliament and' to power aGo- verntnent which bore within it the seeds of dissension. This^was the dominant faotor in. the- eleodon which, combined with the desire to give the other.side a ohanoe, inflorenoed' the waverers whose votes always decide the ' day. The moral is plain and a wholesomo lesscin has been taught by the electorate -fchibh it ia to be hoped the Unionist Party ' ,will take seriously to heart daring the period :that they will have to remain in the oold Bhado of Opposition; Let them Berry their ranks and brace themselves for a straggle in which they will undoubtedly in the long ran snooeed.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA RIOT.
div.p: In the Native Court of Appeal at Alexandria to-day, the appeal of the aoonsed who were sentenced by the lower Court to varying terms pf imprisonmenc .for participation in the now-famous Alexandria ''riot," came on for hearing. The presiding judge was Ahmed Bey Abdin. Three counsel appeared for the appellants, Ibrahim Bey El Heldawi, Ali Bey Aesem, Bnd Musta* Iia B- y Kbadem. The hearing of the case was still proceeding as we went to press.

div.head: A RUMOUR.
div.p: It is rumoured (arid we reproduce the rnmour under every reserve) that the daughter of Ahmed Rateb Pacha, Vali of the Hedjaz, wLo recently anived with her mother and brothers at Port Said; refused to proceed with them to Constantinople and has come on to Alexandria, accompanied by her eldest brother, who will shortly leave her and proceed to the Turkish Capital.

div.head: LUXOR HOSPITAL
div.p: A report on the Lnxnr Hospital for Natives has been issued for the information of those who have shown an interest in the welfare of the institution, and who, by their subsorip tions and in other ways, have furthered its work. While giving a brief aooount of the hospital since, its foundation, it refers chiefly to the condition of the institution at the present time, and includes a description of the hospital, the staff, routine of work, the patients, .book- keeping, finances, etc. During the uiiter season many visiters at Luxor inspect the hospital, and, says the superintendent medical < fficer, "we are glad to welcome them at all rimes. For the convenience of passengers by . tho tourist steamers I arrange to set apart Tuesday afternoons between 2 and 4 p.m for this purpose."

The new floor of tiles in the operating room has proved very satisfactory, and a similar floor has now been laid in the Longmore(snrgi- cal) ward. It is hoped that funds will be available to parry out this very necessary alteration in the other wards and departments. A debt of gratitude is due to Mr. A. Urquhart for his advice; and help in this and other matters. There is row a sufficient Bupply of hot sterilized water in the operating room for all ordinary requirements. An excallent mioroscope was presented to the hospital by Mr. R Mond.

The return of in-patieuta for the year shows a daily average of 21, an increase over any pre- vions year. The out patients' return shows a falling off from 54 to 52. This may, the S. M. 0. thinks, be accounted for by the fact that iast winter season was a particularly healthy one in Egypt. It has been thought advisable (to omit from the report a detailed list of tho medioal and surgioal cases admitted, and that of operations performed, as tho mere technical names of diseases and operations canuot be of much interest to the general reader. They have had fyi treat many various disease?, tropica) and other. Several major operations have beea performed, snch as amputations, trephining, lithotomy, etc, There were also 160 ophthalmic operations oarried onf. Seven deaths ocoorred daring the year due to suppurative pericarditis, oononssion, burns of the whole body, pneumonia, unemia, abscess of liver, and shook after a doable operation.

The total receipts were £887 14s. id., and tho expenditure £954 18s. 2d., leaving a serious deficit of £67 4s. id., which it is hoped to make up this year. The committee, there fore, earnestly appeal to the general publio for such donations and Subscriptions as may snffios to place tho work upon a satisfactory finanoial basis, and may allow the hospital to inorease i'a beneficent operations in a degree oommensurate with the demauds upon them.

The. hospital has been generonsly supported daring the past season, and.its fiaanoial position has been improved, bat too much confidence mast not bo plaoad in this, os so much depends on the number of visitors during the winter seas in; this source of iuonme mnst therefore be a precarious oue, and we would urge the well-wishers of the hospital to contribute by annual subscription in preterenoe to donations.

The subscription lists 'at Lnxor and on the Nile steamers have, as in past years, shown the interest taken in the hospital by, passing tourists. A special appeal is made to the organisers of social functions at Luxor and Assouan to remember the hospital's needs. The general expenses of the hospital inorease every year. Not only are wages and food higher, but there is an increasing number of patients to provide for.

div.head: THE GARRISON DIRECTORY
div.p: We take this opportunity of informing oor readers that the January edition of the Garrison Directory has just been Lsued to the usual booksellers for sale. Many errors which are boaod to appear in a work of this nature hive been oorreoted in the present edition, but it is regretted that some of the emendations which have been received arrived after that portion ot the book had gone to press ; they yvill therefore appear in the next issue, probably 80th Febriiary.The February edition willbasent to presi-.on the 5th February, aud the March e1i'ion, the final one for the season on the bth March. It is . hoped that residents will Vorify their addressee aud will iuform the Clerk in Charge whether the addresses as at present published are oorreot.

It haB long been realised that there are many errors in the residents' lint at the eud of the book, aud it is intended to omit from the March edition every name and address concerning which the Clerk in Charge shall not have received the due notification from the resident interested before the 5 th March. Tho re who have already notified the Clerk in Charge w II of course be retained in the list. The public should bear in mind th-t the March edition firms the basis for the early public* ions of next season's direct jry, and therefore it is very desirable that it should be as oorreot as possible. To make a publication of this nature of -general utility requires the oo-oper/ition ot everybody concerned, and it is hoped that the general publio will each of them take up the matter-as it concerns himself and ensure that the directory is satisfactory to him persopaliy.It would addto the usefulness ofthe book if- the addresses of th« more important residents in Alexandria were included; therefore they are invited to tend in tleir names,

div.head: SHOULD IT BE ABOLISHED
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—I have read with interest your two,, leaders on this subject, although I confess | myself a little surprise 1 at the confident and perfanctory manner in which yon deoide that the law should be abolished or considerably modified. You do not s-em to me to have j sufficiently weighed all the considerations , which should operate before a legislative A change such as you propose sheu'd take place.

I The law of pre-emption is conf;ssedly one i which is only to be found in M 's'em countries, ! but it does not seem to be suffioiently remembered that the Mohamedan law is part and parcel of the Mohamedan religion, and any infringement or derogation from the former is i regarded, and rightly so, as tantamount to tampering with the latter. The spirit which prompts the proposed modification is one the selfishness of which I cannot but depl ire. seeing that there are ninety-two percent, of the population of this country win are strenuously opposed to any such change. It is the spirit of the "Uitlander" transported from Sonth Africa, whioh, if allowed full rein, would eventually bring about the terrible oalamiries which we have so recently seen result in the Transvaal.

Of course, the oiroamstenoea here are not quite the same, for, notwithstanding . the most optimistio reports, gold has not yet been found in suoh paying quantities as to render the eff jrta to oapture it a sufficiently | tempting bait. Bat if the dreams of the spoon- I lators ware realised to morrow it is m7 firm ( balief th»t the last glimmer of Egyptian inde pandeoce would vanish for all time. However, to return from this slight digression,what I wish , olearly to point out is tint beovi^eavory small and insignifioant number of foreigners have oome into the oiuntry and ara enrioh'ng themselves at Egypt's expense, whenever a lav does not tally with thsir views of right and equity, or does not favour the olass of tram- aotions ip which they are engaged, they are fir ruthlessly abolishing it or modifying it beynnd all reoognition without the smallest coaoern as to whether or not it militates* against the us«[es and traditions or even against the religion of the people to whom the oonntry belongs —I am, eto.,
"WATANI."
Cairo, January 22.

div.head: A PANEGYRIC
div.p: DR. ABBATE PACHA'S BROCHURE.

The opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway, whereby becomes realised one of the grandiose dreams of a former monarch of Egypt, is an opportune occasion for the publication of ''Le Soudan.sous le rfegne du Khedive Ismail," by H. E. Dr. Abbate Paoha. The author, iu.a well-printed and neatly-bound broohure, pays avouching tribute to that ill-fated Prince whose-good qualities/be assures as, so far ont- we*gbed his failings as to render the historian imbued" with a s mse of impartiality almost obli- vionsof everything savethegraudeurof the work inaugurated "and achieved under-his auspices. Throughout Abbate Pacha's it ruinous pages there runs a rich vein of eloquence and a wealth of philosophic epigram. For an ootoga- narian this opuBoula is a varitablo ' tour de foroe" whetting our appetites for tha more ambitious ' Aigyptiaca" which is announced soon to follow. The'secret of personjri attract tion exoroised by Ismail Ptoha can o^ily be understood by tho.-e who belonged to his immediate "entourage," though that indefinable quality, according to all aocounta, has descended unimpaired to the present ocoupanj of the Khedivial throne. The charm and fascination of the grandfather seems to have been inherited, without other Iqis desirable attributes, by Abbas Helnsv, to whose patriotism and enlightenment Dr. Abbate pays fitting homage. 8trange to say, ,for "one past life's meridian, Dr. Abbateis no more' laudator temporis aoti." ludeei, the most remarkable feature -of this bejewelled encomium is; its una'loyed optimism, the eenfHeuce in Egypt's future, which is present from beginning to end. The sole note of regret sounded is Dri Abb&te's lament that with Iamail Pacha, as with the world in general,
Tho ovil that men do lives after thorn,
Tho good is oft interred with their bones.

Rumour has it that" "The 8tory of the Khe- divate" may short'y'-be published in a cheap edition, to which the prerent pamphlet will form an appropriate pend*nt, Abbate Pa/ ha stands not alone in,bis paneryrio. A publicist from a colder olime fell equally under the seductive spell of Egypt's former Sovereign, os will be readily observed by all who peruse Mr. Edward Dioey'-s brilliant volume. Happily, we have still amongst us and, at present, in the very oity of .Caiio", two veteran ohampions of a" romantio and exoiting period of Egypt's hie- 'i j tory ; the one, to arouse in loTty and vigorons . | strains the youth of this country to \a j recognition" of the ooarse.of events which have- led to their present prosperity, the other, to point out to his compatriots the direction in whi .h Egypt's true destiny lies. .

BAGDAD RAILWAY.

Of the two railways in Turkey formerly controlled by British capital one only now remains ; the German Anatolian Railway Company having quietly seoured the majority of the shares in the Mersina, Tarsns, and Adana Railway. The object is to make Mersina the seaport terminus of the Bagdad Railway, thn3 saving the cost of the transport of material, and at the same time obviating a possible cou- fl'ot of interests.

The Mersina, Tarsus, and Adana line is aboat 42 miles in length (4ft. 8 jin. gange). and oonaeots Mersina, on fhs Mediterranean, with Adana, in Asia Minor. The concession under which it was built by the Mersina-Adana Constriction Company (Limited) is fixed at 50 years from January 8, 1883, at the expiration of which the railway reverts to the Ottoman Government, and to a piy- ment for all rolling-stock, tool*, plant, and tores. The railway is built as a single line, to admit of the laying of a second set of rails. British control, as regards Tarkish railways, is now only represented by the Ottoman Railway from Smyrna to Said.
THE YEMEN RISING.
It is reported that Feizi Paoha has been trilled in battle with rebels in the Yemen.

The late Feizi Pacha was a man of oommand. irig personality. When be was appointed to the task of quelling the revolt in the Yemen -his fame preoeded him, and his name alone was sufficient to inspire fear in the breasts of the rebels. He had besides the most iitimate knowledge of the insurgent Arabs themselves, having spent nearly all h:s life among thorn, and this knowledge he took fall advantage of in his method of patting down the insurrection. His battles were won as much by taot as by foroe of arms.

Although a man of fortune, and in years, he preferred the hardships of the soldier of the field to living in ease and oomfort. He was essentially a man pf notion, and of that ready deoiB'.on which comes of long familiarity with command and a con'oiousness of past success?

div.head: SLEEPY ALGECIRAS
div.p: PICTURESQUE REVIVAL OF THE
OLD MOORISH TOWN

A'geoiras is a* sleepy lit-.le Andalusiaii-coaht town, whose ten or twelve thousand people live, chufly by fishing, smuggling,- andoffioial- dom. One side) of the harbour is formed by the shore oT a verdant little island called erde, from which the great Arab genoral, Al Tarek, who bnilt t,he town in 713, named it Al-Ghe?;sirab, The Island.

For five or six oentnries after that periol, while the Moors mado a garden of Andelnsia, and gave Christendom a magnificent lead in art, in commeroe, in learning, and in general civilisation, Algeciras was a port of note. ThoD, in the fourteenth century, Alphonso, King of Castile, drove oat the rapidly degenerating Moore and .utterly destroyed Algeciras, Anda Insia was utterly devastated by the Spaniards in the coarse of its recapture, and they have never healed itc wonnde. RoinB of the magnificent squeducte which converted barren hillsides into smiling champaigns and brought the masic of splashing waters into fairy palace court-yards, are to-day, like the crambling remnants tf the'palaces, choked by palmetto and caotas.

It was not until the eighteenth century was more than half /iped thst modern Algeciras, a sort of dim shadow of the fne Moorish port, was reared upon the rains of its forbear's ancient state. Now, .the railway from Boba- dil!x—-English' ballt and owned—makes geciras its terminus, and the company has racent'y opened a great hotel there. An honrly- ranning feny boat plies between the port and Gibraltar,which latter place presents a striking oontrast to piotarerq-ie. sleepy Algeciras, and makes the traveller feel as though he had'been ferried from one age of history into another. The more thriving, useful place of the two is not altogether the more pleasant.
Thm Annual Fair.

Once a year Algeciras roaaes -and decks itself gloriously for a great fair, which is attended by all sorts and conditions of people, and is a very bright and pictnrrsqne event. Algeciras ball fights attract a good many visitors from Gibraltar, English as well as foreign, and the place is used a9 a report by residents of Gibraltar in sammer time. From its background of barren hills * one looks across the sparkling water-rows of the Straits to,the wild,bold ooast- line of the .picturesque realm of bis Sherifian Majesty Abd el Aziz IV. of Morooco. Its stree'a are inohned to be grassy, silent, and peaceful, and if the Moorish delegates who attend the conference happen to be genuinely of the 'ulnmna, or leamel class, they will realise that the place in which they have oome to hear discussion regarding the reformation of their own decadent conntry, is but an insignificant reflection of the city their ancestors fonnded in the spaoious days of a thousand years ago.

div.head: THE VOYAGE OF THE DOCK
div.p: A telegram from New York states that owing to the terrifio weather, fears are entertained for tile safety of the great steel floating dock, Dewey, which weighs over 20,000 tons and is now being towed to the Philippines from America by three powerful tugs, and is to pass through the Suez Canal. Up to Son- day week the dock had not got aoross the Atlantic, and the Navy Department at Washington has instructed the cruiser squadron of the American Atlantic fleet to search for it, and render assistance if required. The tow-lines arc a mile long, end the rate of progress b&rd'y exceeds a man's walking pace. So e'ahorate a towing experiment is unique, and the greatest ooncern for the saccess of the voyage exists throughout the conntry.

div.head: A CLEAR COURSE
div.p: MR. BALFOUR ON THE LESSON
OF THE DEFEAT.

Mr. Balfonr spoke at the Manchester Cental Conoervative Club after the figures had been announced showing his defeat. Hia reception was of the heartiest character, the audience singing ' For ha's a jelly good fellow" with great spirit.
He remarked that they had bean in power ten years, and a reverse was inevitable.

"Wo have seffarei the' common lot," he wanton, "and we shall suffer the common lot in the futare—that is, we shall have to go back to office—(cheers)—and to cofreot, so far as we can, the blunders of our predecessors. (Renewed cheers). Oa that snbject, I have no preoccupations. We shall return inevitably, as inevitably as the seasons return. It is written in the very law of our institutions. It is to be foandin the unwritten law, perhaps I onghtto say, which governs our institutions. Have no a'arm on the score."

Lookin x at the way in which tho Liberals had won, Mr. Balfour said that if he believed their opponents were sincere in what they had premised he should'have Borne donbt about the future of the conntty.
Unionists' Duty.

"At all events," he said, "our oonrse is clear. In this great dif-trict we have lean defeated. We have not only hesn defeated, but we have boon defeated with the utmost feverity and completeness. Oar business is, first, to analyse the causes of the defeat; secondly, to do what we can to remove those causes in so far as they are removable ; and, above all, and more important than all, to wait with onr great organisation ready and prepared antilthe in-! evitable movement of the clock shall bring us to the fat d hour when the constituencies of this great district shall Bee the error they performed, and will make signs of that practical repentance which is sure to oome, and which is the only repentance of which We desire to see the signs, a repentance which will bring them back to the politioal faith to which they have been so long wedded, and which I am ccn-i vinood has not been seriously shaken in the body of thope whom I am addressing, and which has suffered an eclipse, serious, indeed, but not long ; and that we shall meet together soon in this very club—(l\ear, hear) —where I first saw a Lancashire audience, and proclaim again that the Tory and Uuionnt Party has resumed its proper jflaoe in a population which nothing will iuduo£pne to believe is not Conservative and Unionist at heart. (Applause). Confidant of the Futuro.

" Ladies and gentlemen, these are the reflections suggested to me by the catastrophe— I have no desire to minimise facts—these are. the thoughts suggested to me by the oatas- tropln which has just occurred to our party. Tuey are not thoughts gloomy in their character ; they are, on the contrary, full of hope and faith and ooufldenoo in the future ; and if yon share that hope and that oonfidenoe with me depend upon it, the hour in whiob we phall see the fruition of oar desires will not be ldng delayed." (Loud cheers.)
Mr. Balfour afterward« visited. Beveral of |he Conservative clubs in East Manchester Division, and briefly returned thanks lor the exertions of his.supporters on his behalf.
The Moniont of Defeats

Mr. Balfour entered the Town Hall, Manchester, with his sister, just before the checkers' work was completed. When the result was made known, we are told every one hurried from the room after bidding him farewell. He stood there almost deserted, with a look of far-off wonder on his oare-Iined face. But in never looked more dignified them in that moment of great defeat. From withont the tumultuous roar full apod his ears, as the immen-e crowd greeted hia rejection with wild delight. He amilod sadly, and, like one walking in a dream, moved slow'y to the door.

div.head: TEA AS A BEVERAGE
div.p: In an interesting article, which appears in the current number of the "Practitioner," nnder the heading of "The Physio'ogical Action of Tea as a Beverage," Sir Lender Bronton, Consulting Physician to St. Bar ho- lomew's Hospital, points ont that the effect of tea, coffee, or cocoa appears to be three fold, (1) on the circulation, (2) on the spinal cord, and (3) on the brain. Through the effect of these substances on the circulation, the flow of blood through the brain is increased, more nutriment is supplied to the brain cells, and thus thought is quickened. The brain cells, themselves, are also probably affeoted by tea or coffee, so that communication between tli6m becomoi more rapid, more complete, and more permanent than in ordinary oircnmstances, and thus it is that people think more dearly and speak more readily when stimulat d by tea orj coffee. Sir Lander continues:— Unfortunately tea is liable to abuse as well wj use, and just as the bills, which properly employed may greatly help a commercial man, will bring about hopeless bankruptcy if overdrawn, so tea and its ooDgeners, if abused, will bring about the most disastrons results. One of these is a consequenoe of the power of tea to lessen disagreeable sensations, for it not only lessens fatigne ljat it lessens hunger as well, and thus tends to prevent nutriment being taken which would otherwise build up the organism, and restore the energy taken from it by exertion nnder the inflaen.ee of tea. All teas, however good, have this action.bat in addition to it some teas have an injurious effect upon the stomach itself on account of the tannin which they contain. Tannin when taken along with batcher's meat hardens it and renders it less digestible, bo that a meat- tea is often provocative of dyspepsia. Upon farinaceous food it has no such aotion, and the experience of people has shown that bread and butter, toast or rusks, go well with tea. Fish and eggs are, I think, softer than meat, and do not suffer so muoh from the tanning action of the tea, while bacon is already hard and remains nnaffeoted.

It is thus evident that tea may interfere with nutrition in three wAya. First, by lessening the feeling of hungor; second, by rendering food less digestible ; and third, by interfering wjtb the digestive power of the stomach. At the sftme time that it thus lessens the nutrition of the body, it enables the person to use op much more energy than he or she would be able to do without its aid, and the ooDseqaences of this are most evident in regard to the nervous system. Although tea prevents the, sensation of t*it:gue from being felt for a while, yet exhaustion is going on, both in miod and body, and this usually at length oansea disinclination either to mpntal or bodily exertion, and tends to destroy tho power of doing auy nsefnl work, either mental or bodily, even when the attempt is made. Power of self-restraint is diminished, and the person koines n&rvous, nndnly to'sitive, timid, and emotional. ... But, in addition to its action on the nervous system, tea is a powerful stimulant to the oir- onlation, and, if abused, will tend to weaken this, jastas it tends to weaken the nervous system, and will lead to feebleness of the pulse and palpitations.

All teas are not equally injurious. Ceylon and Indian toa are preferred by many people to China tea on account of their aroma and stimulating-qualities, and so long astheyaro taken in moderation and prepared in the right way by .simple infusion for two or three minutes, nnd then pouring the Water off from the leaves, they will suit healthy people very well. But whether it is on aooount of the higher proportion of tannin they oofitain, or some other reason which we do not yet know, they are not so good for weak digestions as China tea, whiob, especially if it is prepared in the way just recommended, by infusion for two or three minutes only, is less likely to cauee dyspepsia than other kinds of tea. ... To sum up shortly what I have said in this paper. Tea, when .properly prepare and taken in moderation, is both nsefal ahd agreeable. Whan taken in too great quantity, or along with butoher's meat, when too strong, when infused too long, or still more when boiled and steweL it is apt to produce digestive troubles. When taken in excess it may proddoe nervous symptoms of the most serious-chataoter, and facilitate, if it does not actually produce, mental degeneration..

. <30ÜR D'APPEL MIXTE
Exception de Jeu

Hassan Bey Hafez, invoquant l'exception de jeu, avait attaqué son courtier- C. Z. Angelo- ponlo, parce que celai-ci s'était porté contre partie dans tontes, les opérations qa'il avait traitées pour son compte.
Se plaçant à ce dernier point de vne, le' tribunal de première instance a oondamné-le conrtier.

Mais, celni ci ayant fait appel de oe juge ment, la^bard'Appel Mixte vient de réforme- la aentabce attaquée : elle déolare l'appel bien tocdé et condamne Hassan Bev Hafez à paye- à la maison appelante la somme de P.T. 29,250, ensemble aux-intérêts^ raison de 7 % l'an à partir de la demande,en justice'; le condamne on outre èn tous les dépens des deux degrés ; convalide enfin, jusqu'à concurrence des pré sentes condamnations en capital, intérêts et frais, les saisies-arrêts pratiquées entre les mains des sieurs Mohamed BeySaï l, Ibrahim Bey Hafez et- Chefik Bey Hafez ^ et telles qu'elles sont spécifiées dans l'exploit du 19 octobre 1904.
Parmi les motifs, il s'en trouve de très intéressants au point de vue de la législation en matière de bourse ; nous allons en donner un court aperçu :

D'abord il n'existe dans la loi aucune prohibition pour' le courtier de se porter contre partie dans un ordre-exéouté pour son client ; oola ressort de la. disposition 'qui lui reconnaît le droit de ne pas faire connaître le nom de son commettant.
Un de3 grands inconvénients de oette législation consiste en ce qi'elle ne permet pas de contrôler les abus auxquels peuvent* se livrer les courtière peu scrupuleux.

En l'espèce donc, la présentation de livres ne pouvait - avoir qu'une utilité, celle de vérifier les prix, mais comme les billet? àotuelle- çaéh't en litige résultent d'on règlement qui suppose l'approbation préalable dés oomptes, cette présentation demeurait sans objet.

Dans cas conditions et la validité des marchés à terme ne pouvant être Bérieüsement contestés, il y a lion de réformer le premier j agencent qui reoonaassait en l'espèce l'exception de jen. Il n'y a qu'un cas ou oelleci peut être admise, c'est lorsqae celui qui en. excipe peut prouver,que le3-opérations en- contestation ne constituaient qn'un pur jen,.soit à- raison de l'intention même des parties intéressées, ou de sa situation précaire

div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: Nouvelles Nominations
Le Tribnnal Mixte d'Alexandrie s'est réuni hier soir à & heures en Assemblée Générale ponr pourvoir de titnlaires les nouveaux postes créés récemment par le Ministère.
Le poste de Greffier figurait en première ligne. Leadenx candidats en présence étaient :

M. Music, avocat, secrétaire de là Présidence, Commis Greffier de la Chambre Civile, et M. Rivelli, Commis-Greffier délégué au bureau institué près les Tribunaux Mixtes pour la passation de certains' aotes notariés.

Tons dens sont d'aotifs et dévoués fonctionnaires qni ont déjà fait leurs preuves an service de la Réforme., Pour dos raisons d'ancienneté sans doute, M. Rivelli l'a emporté sur son collègue, qni do manque certainement pas de capacités, mais dont le tort est d'être trop jeune.
On a également nommé M. de Porto, Commis Greffier et Dalla Rovere, chef dn bnroan des huissiers. On a pourvn ce dernier service do deux nouveaux huissiers.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPLE
div.p: ( Communication Officielle)
La Délégation municipale s'est réunie le 23 janvier 1906 sons la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: MM. Benaohi, Fenderl, Mansour Bey Yonssèf, Soliman Bey Abàni, E. Stross, Dr.' G. Valensiu, G. Zarvudaohi. membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, 1. SedTcy Bey, secrétaire.

La Délégation déoide de demander à la Commission les crédits nécessaires pour la commandé de 15,000 mètres de bordures de trottoirs en prévision des travaox de confection des nouvelles routes, dont le programme est à l'étnde du mité spécial.
Vu l'argence, elle déoide de provoquer dè-i maintenant des. offres ponr la mise en adjn- dicaiion de cette, fourniture dès que la Commission en aura approuvé le crédit.

Relativement s une demande de l'Inspection dn 3me Cercle d'irrigation tendant à installer nr. hangar sar la rive gauche dn Canal Mah- moudieb, la Délégation est d'avis de surseoira oette demande eo attendant que la question relative à la règlement «t:on dn canal ut de ses abords ait reçu une solation ;
La Dé'égation décidé la confection de-caissons de vidanges en régio pour le tranupçrt des matières provenant du curage des égouts de la ville. ^

Le Ministère ay».ut demandé à la Municipalité poar quelle, somme elle serait disposée de contribuer aux frais de oonstrnotion des nouveaux ponts projetés à Minet el Bassal, la Délégation déc'de d'en référer à ja Commission et exprima l'avis que la Municipalité pourrait .se charger de Ta moitié de la déponse, à la condition que le Commerce d'Exportation contribue a.'-* frais que la Muniuipalité aura à supposer de ce chef La Délégation adjuge, pour moitié chaouu, la fourniture du bsraim à M.M. Zaki Tehgmar ew Hemeda Ibrahim et Abiad. Le travail :de confection d'une ronte an
N. B! da fort de Kom el Dick, avec construction, d'an mur de soutènement, est adjugé à M. A: Liri», au prix de L E. 1014, 990 m/m.
La Délégation oharge an comité, composé de MM. Beuachi, Fenderl, Zervadaohi et Abani Bey d'examiner la question relative à la oons traction d'un théâtre et de lai faire rap :porb.
Elle prend note du rapport préliminaire do l'Administrateur sur les comptes de 1905 et approuve diverses demandes de crédits, sauf approbation de la Commission Municipale.
La séance est levés à 7 h. p.m.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
CYRANO DE BERGERAC

Cyrano de Bergerac, fameux duelliste et écrivain barlesqne de l'époque de Richeliea, a été admirablement bien représenté dans là pièce d'Edmond Rostand qai a an conserver an plaisant héros gascon, une originalité des plas savoureuses.
Nous sommes là eu présence d'an véritable chef-d'œnvre dont le saocè éolatant est dû à tontes sorteà de'qualités de U meilleure tradi tiou française.

M. Daragon a oréé de façon merveillense le rôle de Cyrano. Le publie l'a acclamé avec nn véritable enthousiasme. Les autres interprètes ont eu une large part dans le succès. Mme Moreno, dans le rôle malheureusement trop court deP.ozane, a été également remarquable. Les beaux vers d'Ed. Rostand, débités de façon supérienre par Mme Moreno et M. Daragon ont été fort appréciés.

La dissertation de Cyrano/sur son nez, les tirades quelle provoque at,les sublimes déclarations d'amour que Cyrano improvise ponr Christian, amant de sa ooasineRrxaue, la description ducombat et la scène du baiseront été fort applaudies.

En revanche, les Upper Egypt Hotels s'avancent à 5 3/16 et les Eaax da Caire reprennent à 120.*
L'ensemble da marché est soutenu, mais, en dépit d'une grande animation à la corbeille, le nombre d'affaires demeure restreint. Ou a échangé surtout la Banqae les Estâtes, et la Nungoviob.

div.head: OUR PARIS LEITER
div.p: (Ph .m our Correspondent).
Paris, January 16.

It m'ght he a sommpr.'s afternoon on the Biviera, so kindly are the conditions - a bine pkt,.and hot son, end a gentle breeze that has. r.. piker .in it to Btir the slightest twig on the BohlePa'd trees. All the world promenades. To be Chanips Elyses is a mass of vehicles: car- n'ft motor oars, and tbedemopratio taximeter, carrying the ' Parisian to the pleasant alleys of the Boi?. Yon would suppose there wae .no particular tho ght . for the morrow, no care behind the horseman. Nevertheless; France bas.fl'dticient ' snr lea bras" for a Bingle week. AlA iras, the eleotion of the President, oom- plidiionh with Venezaela. Probably, as I write, the.^^nadron of La Martinique is getting up Bteam and pointing its bows towards Southern America. The recall of M. Taegny, the'French Charge d'Affaires, is momentarily expected. A to that nearer matter, the Presidential, Section, the Delegation des Ganches has constituted itself into a vigilance committee sitting permanently, so as to watoh the knavish tricka'of the other aide. Need onereoount all the ''potinii" of the hour! How that the handsome and eloqoent* Paul Deschanel will certainly cone in at the last moment with a tremendous dcoup,' and that other Paul—Paul D.onmer— will have prodigion^ earns at his disposal to bay the support of the Senate and Chamber! Meanwhile, M. Loubet is still considered a possible candidate by some, even though the hoarse-throated "camelot" shouts : ** Dernier testament de M'sien Loubet: dix centimes.

The afternoon, at the Luxembourg, 649 Republican senators an 1 deputies took part in tbo rehearsal vote, and M; Palliates emerged triomphaut^ from the ordeal in the first and only ba'lot. The figures are: M. Failures, 416; M. Donmer, 191; others, 42 in all. So M. Failures has been proclaimed the candi date of the Repi. blioans. Altogether there were 71T members of Parliament at this meeting, all tho Ministers being of the number, as well as M. P.'bot, M. Brisoop, M. Combes, M Moline, M. Millerand, and other well known statesmen. £4. Won Bourgeois had, previously protested against a distribution of voting tickets bearing his name, saying that he had bad nothing to do with it, and had posted up a noti<?e to that effeot on the door of the disused - chapel of the Palace where the meeting took place. There were, of coarse, no speeches, and equally ot course, neither M. Failures nor M. Donmer pat ia an appearanoe. The soooess of M. Fallieres now seems certain. To show the state of pblio 'opinion abont the prospects of the eleotioo, it may be worth while to mention the betting at the Bourse. In a kind of pari mutuel which has just been organised, M. Faliferea has been chosen 790 times, M. Lonbet 300. and M. Donmer 210. As nothing short of a serious emergency would nuke M.'Lonbet come forward as a candidate again, the batting showi that M.- Doom r's chances are thought to be very small indeed. For M "X 'hat is to say, for an nnknown candidate, whose name is not given at all—105 tickiti h*ve bson taken. Besides these, 25 hare been taken for M. Strrien, and 22 for M Adolphe Carnot. About 15 other names have ben eil'dred, bat nono of them attracts more than throe or four. Op Thursday Princess Henry of Battenberg end her charming daughter Princess Ena, the future bride of the young King of Spain, visited Versailles, and w. re shown oyer the ohate&u.

They also in-pected the right wing, where an army of workmen was bn ay getting ready that part of the building for the eleotion of the new President of the Republic. Everything is arranged in luxurious style. The main hall in very ' handsome, and -the presidential chair,
- with its red and gold, lends a bright, note of oolonr to the presidential tribnne. All, Purchase by M. Arnold Fordyoe, acting in over the building, in the numeron. .

In the Umporar, po,t-offiee label, point ont moperatton, and wM Mtonnded at the varion, conn!«, where .tamp, may be I the manner in wlbtoh it ntanoruvred. It wired longht, money-order, proonred, aDd registered h, problem of H.ght b, a body beart.r than letter, attended to It eeeut. that Ptenob the earth's atmosphere. In an article entiled ?*in CaVe of War," the "Bobo de Paris" says : Russia, who ia Franoe's friend and ally, is fully resolved to accept her portion of the responsibilities and to make the nedessary efforts to support France, despite the fact' that her resources have been weakened by the war. From information obtained in well- informed ciroles, it appears that in the event of war between France and Germany, Russia will be able to place on her Western frontier in a comparatively short space of time foartee-i army oorps, which would be brought dp to foil strength by the mobilisation of the reservists. Thia means that Russia oould plaoe on the frontier a force consisting of 518,000 infantry, 52,000 Cavalry, and 1,538 gnns, without iuulud ing any Cossacks or Canoasian troops. This, says the "Bcho de Paris," constitutes an imposing foroe which ix. would be wrong to ignore.

The courageous article in Friday's ' Pall Mall Gazette" has not passe 1 unnoticed. The "Bcho de Paris" devoted to it a column of extracts and comments. The article said what needed to bs said. English unity of policy with France cannot be too mnoh insisted upon. Every despatch from the correspondents at Madrid refers, with gratitude, to the support given to M. RCvoil by 8ir Arthur Nicholson. A fortunate fate, in the shape of an alphabetical order, places them side by side at the board of oonferenoe. It is' a happy angary. The English elections are watohed here, perhaps wrongly, bat, at any rate, naturally, for some sign of the international temper of the British people. Even the intelligent Frenchman is hardly oonBpionons for any great perception of English politics, bat he believes he sees in this startling defeat of Mr. Baifonr something like a new triumph for the "Napo'.Con sans viotoires" as the dominant fignre in Earope has been happily named. The interpretation may be qnite mistakon, but it is understandable.

A* few years ago but dim and hazy descriptions of the great eieotoral fights in England would have reaobed this side of the Channel. It is otherwise now. Long, deaoriptive aooonnts of the behaviour of the eleotion orowds in Fleet-street and the Strand garnish the Paris press to-day.. The foreign observer sees in it some likeness to the excitability of the French in similar oiroamstances. People to whom I have spoken this afternoon inquire what are the chances of Mr. ChimbeiUin. Will this great land mark of Protection be temporarily obliterated by the rising tide of Liberalism 1 Natarally, the oritios who exalt at John Ball's new phase are tho advanced party in the State; bat their oonnsels are apt to be dangerous, as we know by Bad experience. Beware, therefore, of enoh congratulations 0 British people and hasten to adjast the balance.

The step just taken by the Government for enlarging the note issue of the Bank of France, brings out into strong relief the great and steadily inoreasiDg measnre of French indnstrial and oommeroial prosperity. The present limit of the note issue ia two hundred million pounds, guaranteed on bullion and on short dated seonritier. This limit, though only fixed as giving a wide margin so recently as 1897, fas almost been reaohed. To be precise the frotes in oironlation were within £3,500,000 of the limit, or an inorease of notes in oironlation sinoe 1897 of abont £48,000,000. In 1897 the bnliion in tho vanlts was abont £124.000,000. It is now £32,000,000 more, and ie increasing at such a rate that the Bank is faced with the pros pect of being reduced to payments in speoie. To avert each a danger, the note issae is to be increased by £32,000,000

been brought to light the whole of the series o! etchings on copper executed by Rembrandt, and known as the Mariette collection. This fine seres Jot ho great painter's minor works hil for uuny years been lost The disoovery . caccmttlatxd funds has at length been made by a French art perio-; annual uvxnux ... dioal, which has handed over thn whole collection to the Ryks Mnsenm of Amsterdam. The gift is one of great magnificence. No fewer than 85 plates comprise the series, many of them the finest thatever oamefrom Rembrandt's brain. They inolnde such portraits as that of Saskia, Doctor Fanatns, the Descent from the Cross, and the Restoration of Laiarus.
That hnmble handmaiden of fame, the Press- ontting agency, has at last managed to raise around Paelf a question of sufficient praotioal interest to bo worth a test case in litigation.

It was here in Paris, and the '/Emperor of the Sahara," fi'.tingly enough, was tba oentral fignre in the cash. "His Majesty" has (long money so freely that a few pounds more or less for the joy of knowing what the world pays about him should seem to be of small account. Bat the worm will tnm at last, and for M. Lebandy the taming point came when, after paying some £50, he received another aoOount for £10 without having given speoifio orders for farther work. He took the question to law, and the plaintiff agent has just been non-snited, the judge holding that in the absence of an express order no c'aim ooold arise.

The lighter side of life is represented by talk of a deooratioa for Sarah Bernhardt. There is a doubt whether she will have the red ribbon, af:or all. The last recipient—Mile. Bartet, of the Comdiie Frangaise-has created a prece dent from which it would appear to be difficult to esoape, seeing the artistic eminence of "La Divine" But every "sooidtaire" of the House of Molidre is, in a manner of speaking, a functionary of the State; therefore, upon that footing, Sarah's chances are but slender. Mais nous verrons : the last word is always with the Government and not with thd Gonnoil of the Orde-, Ta'.her hostile, than otherwise, io the proposition. Another item of; interest is the proposal to invito a repreientative young woman o! London to take part in the procession of Mi-Carfime.Who will be the London "Qaeen"? A singular honour, surely, to represent the Entente." For the first time in history, the Queen of the Hallos will be neighboured by the Queen of Covent Garden.

A duelling engagement that was intended to be tragic ended in a pleasant oomedy in Paris on Saturday. The party presented themselves in form at the Great Wheel, which is the spot to which all good duellists go for harmless excitement, and were not only admitted, hot condnoted to the spot where honour oonld be tisfiod without interruptior-:. Bnt somehow, having gone so far, the oonoierge was seized with a qualm, and after looking the combatants in, fetched the polioe in all baste. To their surprise, however, they found on arrival that the duellists had vanished, while a ladder against the enolosnre wall indicated the line of escape. Following up this cine the oonoierge fonnd principals and seooncls drinking together in the greatest hilarity outside a neighbouring oafti. They had "mM.e it np" while tho pistols were being loaded, and the oonoierge had great difficulty in escaping from the reconciliation revels.

The ex-prompter of the Comddie Fran^use has committed snioide.The poor man bad been an inmate of Saints Anne's lnnatio asylum for some time. At half past eight o'clock eaoh evening, he fanoiedhelienrdthethreetraditional knooks whioh, in a French theatre, herald the going up of the onrtain. He wonld become very exoited, and declare that the company was waiting for him. "And what will M. Monnet- Sully say ?" he wonld exolaim. Stories are told of other prompters. There was one good man in a bubarban theatre whose own private troubles were revived every time the innooent heroine was carried off by the villaia of the piece. "Ah 1 the soonndrel," he wonld shoat from his box ; "Can they not see what he is doing ?" He woald give audible warnings to the husband to keep his wife clear from all intrigues against her fidelity. These remarks "hors toxte" were a little embarrassing to the aotors and aotresses upon the stage, who were never qaite certain which belonged to the book, and which was the jnvention of the "sonffleur.'' Another member of this hnmble profession was a great Nimrod. His days were spent in shooting. On many occasions, he arrived at the theatre with his bag of partridges and gronnd game. In an evil moment, he brought, also, his retriever. The animal orouohed quietly enough at his feet in the little box below the stage, until he was agitated by the behaviour of the hero, and oommenoed to bark furiously. It was pointed ont to the dog-owner that he was paid to prompt and not to bark, and the spaniel came no more to the theatre.

The German Government reoently issued a list of places abroad in which German oapital was engaged at the end of 1904, and this affords an intelligent insight into the enterprise of oommeroial men in the Fatherland. It is interesting to note that it it is to America, and p&rtionlarly the United States and Canada, that the Germans h&ve direoted the greatest share of attention, and Afrioa, in which Epypt is iuolnded, oomes next with a total oapital invested of nearly £68,000,000.

In Mexico and in certain South American States, the Germans are beginning to feel tte competition of the Yankees, who have praotically gained the monopoly of transport undertakings and alio of the export market; but in Chili, Brasil, and Argentina the position of the German is still very strong. In these oonntrie i the German eleotrioal industry, strongly assisted by the German banka, has fonnd a vast field of operation.
The following is the list, and refers to the oapital represented by the assets of German commeraal houses abroad at the beginning of last year.

div.p: Having regard to German oapital invested in foreign stooks and seoarities, an inquiry made amongst the prinoipal German banking institutions elicited the result that the aggregate may be estimated at least at £E0,0000,001 of whioh about £12',000,000 is sunk in stooks and shares ontside Earope and from £200 000,000 to £300,001,000 invested in Russia and in oonntries of the Neir East.
MORE NEW MILLS IN LANCASHIRE
Mr. William Tattersall, of Manchester, has issued a farther list of new mills that are being ereoted in the County Palatine. This gives details of 66 spinning factories, containing
spindles, and the cost of erection is set down at seven millions sterling. It is ostiirated that employment will be fonnd for

operatives. Seventeen of these mills have reoently got to work, the others being in the course of ereotion, and most of them will be completed by Ootober next. The number of new looms is pat down at 45,000. These will cost about £1,250,000, and will find work for' oloBe upon 13,000 hands.
